liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has turned a corner and picked up some positive gains as we approach 1pm AEST â it's sitting around 0.2% higher at 7,162 points. The reason? Real estate stocks are having a blinder right now â the sector is up 2.4% and leaving the other sectors in the dust. Utilities have gained 1.4%, while basic materials are up 1.1% and academics are 0.4% higher. At the other end, technology is down 1%, while consumer cyclicals are down 0.9% and industrials has shed 0.5%. As for the top movers, it's Magellan Financial's day in the sun: Magellan Financial +19.7% Abacus Property +11.6% Goodman Group +7.9% Inghams +5.5% Core Lithium +5.5% Meanwhile at the other end of the scale: Imugene -13.3% Domain -6.7% Centuria Capital -5.3% Super Retail Group -5.1% Growthpoint Properties -3.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX makes up some ground, all thanks to real estate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's quickly dip back to the US for a moment and look at some other interesting news about their housing market. This week the US's popular 30-year fixed mortgage rate hit the highest level since April 2002, with the average shooting up to 7.09%, according to mortgage finance agency Freddie Mac. That's up from 6.96% last week, and is nearly a full 2 percentage point higher than where it was this time last year. The average 15-year rate also surged to 6.46%, up from 6.34% the previous week â and is also the highest level since April 2002. The jump in mortgage rates comes as the yield on the 10-year Treasury note yield, which acts as a benchmark for mortgage rates, hit their highest level in 10 months â supported by concerns that strong domestic demand in the US could give the Federal Reserve a reason to lift rates again. "The last time the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage exceeded seven percent was last November, " said Freddie Mac's chief economist Sam Khater. "Demand has been impacted by affordability headwinds, but low inventory remains the root cause of stalling home sales."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US 30-year fixed mortgage rate jumps to a 21-year high

items.synopsis: China's infamous censors are methodical about keeping the country's closed internet free from information that the ruling Communist Party does not want its citizens seeing, but a new report from Human Rights Watch findsÂ racist content on the Chinese internet targeting black people has become common.

image.altText: A man with short fair hair, wearing a sleeveless shirt, stands with his back turned and his right arm raised up to a wall.
